Active metal oxide-nitrogen-doped carbon hybrid catalysts towards selective catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol Yaru Xu Methodology Validation Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft Zhaoyang Xu Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Zhidong An Formal analysis Junmou Zhou Formal analysis Jiang Li Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, China College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum (Beijing) Beijing 102249 China College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) recently attracts significant attention in biorefinery due to the free of using high-pressure fossil-derived H2 that potentially reduce the equipment cost. Herein, up to 20 kinds of metal oxide-nitrogen-doped carbon (MOx-N-C) hybrid catalysts are prepared via a hydrothermal method followed by heat treatment under argon, and the successful preparation of such hybrid catalyst is confirmed by various means. Al is found to be the best element to construct such hybrid catalyst towards CTH, giving 96.6% yield of furfuryl alcohol at 99.3% furfural conversion at 120 oC for 6 h. By combining various characterization techniques, the deactivation and regeneration of AlOx-N-C catalyst is attributed to the change in specific surface area, pore volume, and the number of oxygen vacancies. The excellent catalytic performance of AlOx-N-C catalysts provides a broader prospect for its utilization in other biomass conversions as catalysts or active supports. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Biomass conversion Transfer hydrogenation Furfural Heterogeneous catalysis Hybrid catalyst 1 Introduction Seeking sustainable resources to replace fossil feedstock for the production of fuels and commodity chemicals is a hot research topic in the last decade [1,2]. As the only sustainable carbon source on earth, the valorization of lignocellulosic biomass, often named biorefinery, attracts significant attention because of its wide availability [3]. Due to the complex structure of biomass, platform chemicals, first proposed by the US Department of Energy (DOE), and then renewed by Bozell et al., are inevitably required as key intermediates in biorefinery [4,5]. For example, 5-hydroxymethyl furfural and levulinic acid, which are prepared by hydrolysis of C6 sugars, can be used to produce a variety of fuel candidates and value-added chemicals [6–8]. Among the platform chemicals, furfural (FFA) is probably one of the most important. It is the only biomass-derived, unsaturated, commercially available, organic chemicals with an annual production of 300,000 tons [9]. The diverse functional groups in FFA furnish multiple reaction pathways to prepare biofuel and biochemical. Indeed, furfuryl alcohol (FOL) is one of the most attractive FFA derivatives, which can be used to produce resins, synthetic fibers, and some fine chemical products, such as vitamin C, lysine, etc [10–13]. The industrial production of FOL from FFA generally involved a copper–chromite oxide-catalyzed hydrogenation process [14]. Various Cr-free catalysts are further developed to avoid potential severe pollutions during disposal of the catalysts due to the toxicity of Cr. Even such traditional hydrogenation can be realized at room temperature, the use of noble metals significantly increase the process cost [15,16]. When non-noble metal catalysts are employed, high-pressure H2 are needed, increasing the equipment cost [13,17]. In addition, although the production of “green hydrogen” via water splitting or biomass gasification recently attracted significant attention, commercial hydrogen is still mostly generated from non-renewable fossil reserves [18–20]. Thus, an alternative approach, usually named catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH), has recently attracted significant attention for the reduction of biomass-derived molecules especially FFA [21–23]. Various catalysts have recently been reported (Table S1), including metal catalysts based on Pd [24–26], Pt [27–32], Ru [33–35], Ir [36,37], Au [38,39], or non-precious transition metals such as Cu [40,41], Ni [42,43], Mo [34,44], Co [45,46], Fe [47,48]. In addition, some Hf or Zr-based solid acid-base catalysts are also recently recommended due to good catalytic efficiency under mild reaction conditions [49–53]. Notably, some simple metal oxides or metal oxides-carbon hybrid catalysts also exhibited good performance towards CTH. For example, Pasini et al. reported that MgO can catalyze the CTH of FFA in methanol, affording 100% yield of FOL at 160 oC for 3 h [54]. López-Asensio et al. used commercial aluminas for CTH of FFA to FOL, giving a yield > 90% at 150 oC in 6 h [55]. Koppadi et al. reported a carbon-MgO composite for the CTH, affording 98% yield of FOL at 180 oC in fixed bed quartz down flow reactor [56]. Kim et al. reported that alumina–carbon composite material gives 95.8% yield of FOL at 130 oC after 6 h [57]. Such catalysts generally follow a reaction mechanism named Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley mechanism, where acidic or basic property is quite important for the CTH activity [21]. We previously reported the first example of CTH of FFA over Fe catalysts [47]. Our consecutive study shows that the fabrication of carbon-metal oxide hybrid can increase catalyst acidity, thus leading to better activity towards acid-catalyzed reactions such as dehydration or deoxygenation [58,59]. In this case, here we construct up to 20 kinds of metal oxide-nitrogen-doped carbon hybrid catalysts, and the CTH activity of which is investigated. Surprisingly, AlOx-N-C exhibits the best performance, giving 96.6% FOL yield at 99.3% conversion of FFA at 120 oC in 6 h. Besides the Lewis acidity and basicity, the amount of oxygen vacancy, specific surface area, and pore volume are underlined in this work especially for the deactivation and regeneration of AlOx-N-C catalyst. As the metal oxide-nitrogen-doped carbon hybrid catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance towards CTH reactions, such hybrid holds great potential to act as catalysts or good supports towards other important conversions such as hydrodeoxygenation of plant oil-derived glyceride to diesels [58] or upgrade of plastic residue to hydrocarbons [60]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 List of chemicals Aluminium isopropoxide (99.99%), ferric acetylacetonate (98%), Zirconium(IV) oxynitrate hydrate (99.5%), chromic(III) nitrate nonahydrate (99.99%), manganese acetate (99.99%), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (99.99%), lithium acetate (99.99%), titanium(IV) isopropoxide (99.9%), tin chloride dihydrate (99.99%), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (99.9%), magnesium chloride hexahydrate (99.99%), cupric nitrate (99.99%), cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.5%), ammonium metatungstate (99.5%), and antimony acetate (97%) were purchased from Aladdin reagent Co., LTD. Zinc nitrate (99%), potassium hydroxide (85%), chitosan (BR), tetraethyl silicate (AR), barium acetate (99%), isopropyl alcohol (99.5%), and ethyl alcohol (99.5%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. LTD. Activated carbon (99%), benzyl alcohol (99.0%), FFA (98.0%), and FOL (97.0%) were purchased from TCI Chemical Industrial Development Co. LTD. Calcium acetate (98%) were purchased from Shanghai Yuanye Biological Technology Co., LTD. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts used in this paper were synthesized via a hydrothermal method. A typical procedure is as follows：. To prepare AlOx-N-C catalyst: 4 g of aluminum isopropoxide (Mw = 204.24, ca. 20 mmol) was first added to 50 mL of deionized water at room temperature. After a complete dissolution, 1 g of chitosan was then added to the solution at room temperature for 30 min. The molar ratio of aluminum isopropoxide to chitosan was approximately 3.23:1. The mixture was transferred to a teflon-lined autoclave, and then placed in an oven at 180 oC for 8 h. The solid was isolated from the resulted mixture via centrifugation at 10000 rpm for 10 min, followed by washing with ethanol for three times. Then the solid was dried overnight, and was then ground into fine powder for heat treatment in a tube furnace under argon. The temperature program is as follows: 20 oC hold for 60 min, then ramp 10 oC min-1 to 800 oC and hold for 2 h. AlOx or N-C catalysts were prepared using same method as AlOx-N-C catalyst without the addition of N-C precursor chitosan or Al precursor aluminum isopropoxide. The dosage of aluminum isopropoxide was changed to 15 mmol, 10 mmol and 5 mmol to prepare AlOx-N-C catalyst with different ratios of Al/N-C. Other MOx-N-C catalysts were prepared with the same method as AlOx-N-C catalyst using corresponding metal salts as listed in Section 2.1. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was performed in an A300–10/12 EPR instrument from Bruker, Germany. Solid-state MAS NMR spectra were performed on the JNM-ECZ600R spectrometer. Raman spectra were performed on a Raman spectrometer (Renishaw, λ = 532 nm，UK). The content of metal element was detected by ICP-OES (Agilent, USA). The sample was digested with 5 mL hydrofluoric acid and 2 mL nitric acid at 180 °C for 6 h before analysis. Element analysis (C, H, and N) was conducted on the ONH863 and CS844 analyzer instrument from Recoby, USA. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on an X-ray diffractometer with Cu K radiation (TTR-III, Rigaku Corp., Japan) a 2θ range of 10–80o. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo-VG Scientific, USA) with monochromatic Al Kα source (1486.92 eV). For NH3 or CO2-TPD tests, 100 mg catalyst was first loaded in a quartz reactor, and then heated to 500 °C under argon for 2 h. Subsequently, the adsorption of NH3 or CO2 was achieved at 40 °C for 1 h. The catalyst was then flushed with argon for another 1 h, and then heated to 700 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. The desorbed NH3 or CO2 was measured by a gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption is performed on an ASAP2020M adsorption analyzer. BET and BJH methods are used to calculate the surface area, and the pore size and distribution, respectively. 2.4 Experimental procedure The CTH reaction is carried out in a 15 mL of thick wall tube that purchased from Syntheware. For a typical procedure, 0.5 mmol of FFA, 50 mg of catalyst, and 3 mL isopropyl alcohol solvent were added into a glass tube, and the mixture is stirred in an oil bath at 120 oC for 6 h. After reaction, 0.5 mmol benzyl alcohol was added into the liquid product as internal standard, and then the mixture was subjected to GC for quantitative analysis. The temperature program is: 40 oC hold for 1 min, ramp 5 oC min-1 to 120 oC, and then ramp 10 oC min-1 to 240 oC for 5 min. A representative GC spectrum is shown in Fig. S1. Some important reactions have been repeated twice or more to ensure the reproducibility of our experimental results. The conversion of FFA and yield of FOL are calculated as per mole %： Conversion = 1 − molar amount of FFA after reactio n molar amount of FFA before reaction × 100 % Yield = molar amount of FOL after reaction molar amount of FFA before reaction × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening To seek the most active MOx-N-C catalysts, up to 20 elements are screened. Nearly all elements are metals except silicon. The examined metal elements include: 1) main group elements, including IA group such as Li and K, IIA group such as Mg, Ca, and Ba, IIIA group such as Al, IVA group such as Sn, and VA group such as Sb; 2) transition metals such as Ti, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Zr, Mo, and W. Detailed methods for the preparation of MOx-N-C catalysts are shown in Experimental Section. The catalytic performance of MOx-N-C catalysts towards CTH of FFA is shown in Fig. 1. The control experiment without using any catalyst gives 9.25% conversion of FFA and 0.12% yield of FOL. Thus, the CTH reaction cannot proceed spontaneously. It can be clearly seen that the type of oxides has a significant influence on the catalytic activity of MOx-N-C. Thus, the elements are classified into five groups based on their performance. Al is the only element in group I due to its extraordinary catalytic performance, affording a 96.6% yield of FOL at a 99.3% FFA conversion. Cr and Zr are classified into group II, affording 60–80% FFA conversions. The elements giving 20–40% FFA conversions are classified into group III, including K, Mn, Co, Ni, and Zn. For elements of group IV, the conversion of FFA is less than 20%, but still slightly higher than that of N-C catalyst. The elements that afford inferior FFA conversions to N-C catalyst are classified into group V. The gaps between FFA conversion and FOL yield are attributed to the formation of by-products such as FFA-derived acetals, FOL-derived ethers, or aldol condensation product of furfural and acetone [47]. The co-existence of oxides and N-C in MOx-N-C catalysts is confirmed by various means. First, the appearance of MOx-N-C catalysts is quite different from those of MOx catalysts, confirming the presence of N-C. For instance, the color of AlOx-N-C catalyst is black, while the color of AlOx catalyst is white (Fig. S2). In addition, the high angle annular dark field microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and the corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images of AlOx-N-C ( Fig. 2) clearly show the presence of AlOx rods and N-C flakes. Secondly, with similar preparation methods, the weights of most MOx-N-C catalysts are much heavier than N-C catalysts (Table S2), demonstrating that metal oxides are simultaneously fabricated with N-C. However, we notice that some elements, for example Zn, lead to ZnOx-N-C catalyst that has almost the same weight as N-C catalysts. To confirm the co-existence of N-C and Zn in the ZnOx-N-C catalyst, elemental analysis and ICP-AES are performed (Table S3). The contents of C, H, N, and Zn are 37.28, 1.31, 5.28, and 42.2 wt%, respectively, confirming the success fabrication of ZnOx-N-C catalysts. Finally, to further prove the existence of MOx, the XRD patterns of five representative catalysts that depicted from five groups are shown in Fig. 3a. Peaks of Al2O3 (PDF #29–0063), ZrO2 (PDF #49–1642), ZnO (PDF #79–0208), and TiO2 (PDF #89–4921 for anatase phase and PDF # 87–0920 for rutile phase) are found in corresponding XRD patterns of MOx-N-C catalysts. For FeOx-N-C catalyst, only peaks of metallic Fe are found in the XRD patterns, showing the complete reduction of Fe oxides by carbon at elevated pyrolysis temperature. It is generally believed that the acidity of the catalyst is critical to CTH activity. Therefore, NH3-TPD was used to determine the acidity of AlOx-N-C, FeOx-N-C, ZnOx-N-C, and N-C catalysts. The desorption curve of NH3 is shown in Fig. 3b, and the quantitative results are shown in Table S4. The order of the total acid content is: AlOx-N-C>FeOx-N-C>ZnOx-N-C>N-C. Among them, N-C is dominated by weak acid sites, and the amount of desorbed NH3 is 11 μmol NH3/g. The acidic sites of FeOx-N-C are mainly strong acid sites, while ZnOx-N-C dominated by weak acid sites. The total amount of acidic sites of FeOx-N-C is greater than that of ZnOx-N-C. However, the activity of ZnOx-N-C is stronger than that of FeOx-N-C, indicating that strong acid sites have a limited effect on CTH activity. The AlOx-N-C catalyst has the highest total acid sites content, especially for the weak and medium strong acid sites. The basicity of the catalysts are also explored (Fig. S3 and Table S5), and the AlOx-N-C catalyst also exhibits the strongest basicity. Thus, the acidity and basicity of the MOx-N-C catalysts may greatly influence their CTH activity. 3.2 Effect of reaction temperature To investigate the effect of reaction temperature, the catalytic performance of five representative catalysts that depicted from five groups is examined at 80, 120, and 160 oC. Catalysts depicted from group III (Zn), group IV (Ti), and group V (Fe) always exhibited inferior catalytic performance even at elevated temperature such as 160 oC. By comparison, Al and ZrOx-N-C catalysts afford much higher FFA conversion and FOL yield. At 80 oC, AlOx-N-C catalyst gave 72.8% yield of FOL at 75.5% conversion of FFA after 16 h, and 22.1% yield of FOL is achieved at a 25.6% conversion of FFA over ZrOx-N-C catalyst. When the reaction temperature is raised to 120 oC, the reaction rate is significantly improved. 96.6% yield of FOL is achieved after only 6 h for AlOx-N-C catalyst, and 63.2% yield of FOL is produced over ZrOx-N-C catalyst. At 160 oC, the initial reaction rate over ZrOx-N-C catalyst was significantly improved. 40.9% yield of FOL is obtained after 1 h while only 11.5% yield of FOL is produced at 120 oC. The AlOx-N-C catalyst still exhibited better catalytic performance than Zr catalysts, where 93.1% yield of FOL is obtained at 94.8% conversion of FFA in only 1 h. Thus, AlOx-N-C catalyst is the most active CTH catalyst among all MOx-N-C catalysts. The hot filtration experiments (Fig. S4) indicated that the reaction was indeed driven by the heterogeneous catalyst, not by any soluble complex in the solution. ( Fig. 4). 3.3 Effect of the composition of hybrid catalyst To investigate the influence of each component in AlOx-N-C catalysts, the catalytic performance of AlOx and N-C catalyst are examined and compared with that of AlOx-N-C catalyst ( Fig. 5a). The AlOx and N-C catalysts are prepared via methods similar to AlOx-N-C but without addition of N-C precursor (chitosan) or Al precursor (aluminium isopropoxide), respectively. The XRD pattern of AlOx is similar to AlOx-N-C catalyst (Fig. 5b). However, it exhibited inferior catalytic performance to AlOx-N-C catalyst under identical reaction condition, affording 59.2% FOL yield at 62.3% FFA conversion. The N-C catalyst exhibited very poor CTH activity, giving 3.2% FOL yield at 4.8% FFA conversion. Poor porosity is observed in the N-C catalyst (Fig. 5c), and its BET surface area and pore volume are only 0.96 m2/g and 0.0023 cm3/g, respectively (Table S4), much lower than those of AlOx catalyst (94 m2/g and 0.46 cm3/g). Such values are further enhanced to 154 m2/g and 0.55 cm3/g, respectively, for the hybrid catalyst, leading to a better exposure and access to the active sites. We further used EPR, XPS, and NH3-TPD to explore the difference between AlOx-N-C and AlOx catalysts. The amount of oxygen vacancy in AlOx-N-C is higher than that in AlOx (Fig. 5d), in consistence with their CTH activity. The importance of the amount of oxygen vacancy will also be discussed in next section. In O XPS spectrum of AlOx catalyst (Fig. 5e), the peak located at lower binding energy (530.83 eV) is attributed to lattice oxygen, while peak at higher binding energy (531.96 eV) can be ascribed to bridging hydroxyls [61]. The content of oxygen vacancy in AlOx catalyst is 41% as calculated from the atomic percent of bridging hydroxyls [61]. By comparison, lattice oxygen cannot be deconvolved in the XPS spectrum of the AlOx-N-C catalyst. Thus, a higher content of oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface of AlOx-N-C is confirmed, leading to a stronger EPR signal and excellent catalytic performance. In addition, a new peak for nitrogen species that bound with metal (Al-N in this work) [47] is observed in the N1s spectrum of AlOx-N-C catalyst (Fig. 5f) as compared to N-C catalyst, also leading to a higher binding energy of Al (Fig. 5g). NH3-TPD profiles confirmed that the acidity of the AlOx-N-C catalyst is mainly derived from AlOx (Fig. 5h). Overall, the electronic structure of the catalyst is significantly changed after the fabrication of hybrid catalyst, greatly influencing their catalytic performance. The effect of mass ratio of Al precursor to N-C precursor is also investigated. The decrease of the ratio from 4:1–3:1 just leads to slightly lower CTH activity. However, the catalytic performance of AlOx-N-C catalysts significantly decreased when the ratio further decreased to 1:1 or 0:1, giving 68.4% FOL yield at 75.3% FFA conversion and 4.8% FOL yield at 3.2% FFA conversion, respectively. Thus, aluminium oxide is indispensable for the CTH activity of AlOx-N-C catalyst. Raising the ratio to 5:1 or 6:1 leads to slightly decreased FFA conversion or FOL yield. We also explored the effect in other catalysts (Fig. S7). The optimal ratio of Zr precursor to N-C precursor is also 4:1 for ZrOx-N-C catalyst. For other catalysts with much inferior CTH performance, the CTH activity is nearly unchanged when changing the mass ratio. Thus, the results in Fig. 1 can generally represent the performance of corresponding MOx-N-C catalyst, and Al is the best element to construct corresponding MOx-N-C catalyst for CTH. ( Fig. 6). 3.4 Recyclability and reaction pathway The recyclability of the AlOx-N-C catalyst is investigated as shown in Fig. 7a. Unfortunately, inferior catalytic performance is observed during tests. The examination of reaction solution showed just slight leaching of Al (0.05 and 0.29 wt% in the 1st and 2nd runs, Table S6), suggesting that catalyst leaching is not the main reason for the significant deactivation. The EPR spectrum of used AlOx-N-C catalyst is examined, and a much weaker signal is observed (Fig. 7b). To recover the catalytic activity, the catalyst is heated again at 800 oC under Ar after 3rd run. Gratifyingly, 63.9% yield of FOL is obtained at 70.8% conversion of FFA, and a more intense EPR signal is observed in the spectrum. We also used 27Al-MAS NMR to check the coordination of Al in fresh, used, and regenerated AlOx-N-C catalysts [62] (Fig. 7c). Two peaks at ca. 10 and 72 ppm indicate hexa-coordinated Al (Al[6]) and tetra-coordinated Al (Al[4]), respectively. Al[6] species are dominant in our catalysts. In the fresh AlOx-N-C catalyst, the content of Al[6] is 76%, and the content of Al[4] is 24%. The content of each species is nearly unchanged in used or regenerated AlOx-N-C catalysts, indicating that the change in the coordination of Al is not the reason for the deactivation or regeneration. Furthermore, the acidity (Fig. 7d) and the specific surface area and pore volume ( Table 1) of three AlOx-N-C catalysts are explored. Quantitative analysis of the acidity showed that the amounts of weak and medium strong acidic sites are almost unchanged after deactivation or regeneration. As strong acidic sites have been proven not important for the CTH reaction (Section 3.1), the acidity of AlOx-N-C catalyst is not related to its deactivation and regeneration. The BET specific surface area and pore volume of fresh AlOx-N-C were 154 m2/g and 0.55 cm3/g, respectively. When the catalyst is deactivated, the BET specific surface area and the pore volume are reduced to 126 m2/g and 0.50 cm3/g, respectively. After regeneration, the BET specific surface area and the pore volume were restored to 154 m2/g and 0.62 cm3/g, respectively. This is consistent with the decrease or recovery of the CTH activity. As shown in Fig. S1, by-products such as aldol condensation product of furfural and actone are observed after CTH reaction. In addition, FFA is instable due to the easy polymerization to humins. Thus, the surface of the catalyst may adsorb such by-products, leading to less surface active sites and pore block, thereby significantly deactivating the catalyst. This deactivation will be partially restored after high temperature heat treatment under inert atmosphere. In summary, we finally concluded the reason for deactivation and regeneration of AlOx-N-C catalyst to the change in specific surface area, pore volume, and the number of oxygen vacancies. Finally, we try to propose the reaction pathway for the CTH of FFA over AlOx-N-C catalyst ( Scheme 1). For catalysts with acid sites, a classic Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) reduction mechanism is usually involved [63–66]. In our AlOx-N-C system, Al atoms are acidic sites, and the adjacent oxygen vacancy can be considered as basic site. The furfural molecule is adsorbed onto Al atoms, and isopropanol is adsorbed in the oxygen vacancy. Then a six-member ring is formed to accomplish the CTH reaction, releasing the FOL product and acetone. The oxygen vacancy may be occupied by by-products during reaction, which is unlikely to be in-situ recovered, leading to inferior catalytic performance during recycling tests. Another heat treatment under Ar leads to considerate recovery of activity (Fig. 7a). Further efforts will be devoted into the exploration of in-situ regeneration through further structure modification such as heterometallic atoms-doping. 4 Conclusions In this work, up to 20 kinds of MOx-N-C catalysts are prepared via a hydrothermal method for catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of furfural to furfuryl alcohol. The successful preparation of the hybrid catalyst is confirmed by various means, and the screening of oxides showed that Al is the best element to synthesize the hybrid catalyst, giving 96.6% yield of furfuryl alcohol at 99.3% furfural conversion at 120 oC in 6 h. The characterization especially EPR and N2 adsorption/desorption suggests that the change in specific surface area, pore volume, and the number of oxygen vacancies contribute to the deactivation and regeneration of AlOx-N-C catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance of AlOx-N-C catalysts provides a broader prospect for its utilization in other biomass conversions as catalysts or active supports. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) recently attracts significant attention in biorefinery due to the free of using high-pressure fossil-derived H2 that potentially reduce the equipment cost. Herein, up to 20 kinds of metal oxide-nitrogen-doped carbon (MOx-N-C) hybrid catalysts are prepared via a hydrothermal method followed by heat treatment under argon, and the successful preparation of such hybrid catalyst is confirmed by various means. Al is found to be the best element to construct such hybrid catalyst towards CTH, giving 96.6% yield of furfuryl alcohol at 99.3% furfural conversion at 120 oC for 6 h. By combining various characterization techniques, the deactivation and regeneration of AlOx-N-C catalyst is attributed to the change in specific surface area, pore volume, and the number of oxygen vacancies. The excellent catalytic performance of AlOx-N-C catalysts provides a broader prospect for its utilization in other biomass conversions as catalysts or active supports.
coredata.dc:title: Active metal oxide-nitrogen-doped carbon hybrid catalysts towards selective catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol
